The asymptotic growth rate indicates that the integration

d x d y
describes the influence of the source and the destination functions in the early phases of population growth. Therefore, hereafter we call

a spatial factor
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$F_{{\text{h}}}$$\end{document}
F h
of the long-distance dispersal. Note that the spatial factor reduces to 1 for both source- and destination-mediated dispersal models. For the full models of which source and destination functions are

, respectively, we can reduce the spatial factor
